playerItems.h1: Mizoram Sees Alarming Rise in Cancer Incidence and Mortality

playerItems.p: Mizoram, India's second least populated state, has the highest cancer incidence rate, with a consistent uptick in cancer cases and deaths.
Stomach cancer is the leading cause of cancer-related deaths among men in Mizoram, while lung cancer is prominent among women.
Cancer rates are rising among the younger generation, potentially due to lifestyle and dietary factors within the tribal population.
Lack of specialized diagnostic facilities, skilled professionals, genomic research-guided treatment, and transportation issues contribute to rising mortality rates.

Cancer is the second leading cause of death worldwide. Lung, prostate, colorectal, stomach, and liver cancer are common in men, while women commonly face breast, colorectal, lung, cervical, and thyroid cancer.

The most prevalent cancer sites in Mizoram include stomach, head and neck, lung, esophagus, colorectal, liver, urinary, non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, prostate, lung, cervical, breast, stomach, head and neck, colorectal, esophagus, liver, and ovarian cancers among men and women.
A study estimates a 12.8% increase in cancer cases by 2025 in India, with lung and breast cancers being the leading types.

playerItems.h1: Parliamentary Committee Delays Adoption of Criminal Law Replacement Bills

playerItems.p: The Parliamentary Standing Committee on Home Affairs postponed the adoption of draft reports for three Bills replacing existing criminal laws due to Opposition pressure for more time.
Three members, including Adhir Ranjan Chowdhary and Digvijay Singh, filed dissent notes, demanding changes in the proposed criminal laws.
The Hindi nomenclature of the Bills is a key point of contention, with the draft reports not accepting it.
The draft report has accepted suggestions for the Bharatiya Sakshya, meant to replace the Indian Evidence Act, with unanimity.
Opposition members argue that the committee's 12 meetings on the Bills are inadequate considering their significance.
The committee's chairman withheld the draft reports at the last meeting, drawing criticism from Trinamool Congress MPs who had made special efforts to attend.
The committee has scheduled its next meeting for November 6 to allow members more time for review and suggestions.
